betterquesting:10.desc:8: Welcome to GTOW! Thanks for choosing to play this pack, starting off is easy! Just grab a bit of wood and you'll be doing great!
Gravel is a very important material to have in the early game, it often generates near rivers and oceans and there are even some entire beaches of it! Grab that gravel!

To get into crafting you'll need some bark, which you can get through breaking wood blocks with a knife, to get a knife you'll need some flint and a stick, if you craft the gregtech knife, however, you can recraft it into a Roots one.

With your newfound knife you can start knapping up wood to get bark! Right click on some vanilla wood to get that respective bark.

§cTHIS ONLY WORKS ON VANILLA BARK! §fChanges are pending for this.

Do you have too many books? Of course you do! The Akashic Tome solves that issue by consolidating all mod guidebooks you obtain into one central book, including this here questbook! Hopefully the documentation in this is enough, but§ §f in case we are too dumb and don't put in enough information you always have the books to look back on.
Finally you can obtain a crafting table, it's as simple as two bark and two logs. At last 3x3 stations it only took- what 3 minutes?

Rustic is a pretty neat mod

In order to progress in food quests and in agriculture you need to set up basic alchemy with rustic. You need an alchemic condensor with two alchemic retorts, some sort of fuel, water, and glass bottles for any recipe. You can also use these to make potions with Rustic crops, which can be helpful and powerful.
Because of your lack of tools, you don't have much access to stone yet, luckily you can still get fragments of stone by shift right clicking on stone with your knife

The Roots Pestle and Mortar is the first major step in order to get blank patterns. In order to use this item you have to place the mortar on the ground and put the respective ingredients in, then you can mix it together. Later you will get a way better mortar, but that's not right now.
Wood Pulp is gotten by pulverizing a log in a mortar and pestle. Later you can get two pulp per piece, but right now it's one to one
The base for tool crafting is now available, enjoy your freedom

Roots and Rustic are simultaneously the first magic mods you can get into. While Rustic is more of a primitive tech mod, Roots is the major magic enabler at the start of the pack. Both have a heavy focus on nature so you'll need to get your green thumb on.

The quest here is to make a pyre, this is normally meant to be lit with a flint and steel, but without steel you'll need a different type of firestarter, like a match. While you can't light a Pyre with a match, lighting the ground next to it will cause the Pyre to begin doing rituals.

§cBoth Rustic and Roots are highly in development and are still being worked on, not all recipes are finished, bear with it.

Go to GregTech jail

The soft hammer is the first real GregTech tool you can make, it can be crafted out of 6 planks and a stick in a regular hammer formation. This is required for basic technology making.

The nether, while being a dangerous place, has some fairly useful ores. Some of these ores are just more concentrated veins of what you've already seen in the overworld, however some of these veins are brand new and are integral for your progression.

The most important two veins you'll need to find are a sulfur vein and a nether quartz vein. Sulfur is needed to make your first bits of rubber while nether quartz is a valuable gemstone to have for sharpening tools and making glasses.

Don't worry about the veins looking like they can have any type of ore in JEI, because they only spawn in the nether they will only be nether ores!

§cMost Nether Ores spawn near the top or throughout the nether, very few spawn down low. Keep this in mind when digging for veins.

No, not quite yet.

At this current point you do not have the ability to make chests, sorry about that. Luckily for you, completing this quest will give you some chests in case your inventory is filled. All it takes is some wood.

You can make small storage crates, which only hold one item in them. These are required for both the pattern chest §cdont use regular chests for the pattern chest §0§fand drawers, drawers being the best form of storage you can craft right now.

Combining all of your current tools and gizmos together should allow you to make the 4 tinkers work stations. This pack unifies all of the part builders and stencil tables into one, so no need to worry about having the correct type of wood.
With your tools it is now very easy to gather a lot of these basic materials, like sand and clay. You'll need these materials to make better blocks for protection and for primitive technology.
Flint tools are the easiest ones to make as of yet, and the most durable. This quest wants you to get a flint axe, pickaxe, and shovel.
A brick form is required for brick making, obviously. You'll need just about every brick you can make with this, so you'll be using it a lot.
Cobblestone is a great and sturdy building material, as well as an important item in crafting. Get your pickaxe to work now!
Hammers are an important tool in most GregTech crafting, but because you don't have metals and cannot make a furnace, your first hammer will be made out of cobblestone.

Grout is a handy compound made of clay, sand, and gravel. You'll need it specifically for both the Seared Furnace (First proper furnace in the pack) and the Smeltery (First way of obtaining Iron). You'll end up needing a lot of it, almost 2 stacks for the furnace alone.

To make grout you need to throw one sand, one gravel, and one clay dust into a body of water and it will consume the water, because of the fact that there is finite water in the pack you need to do this one at a time. Later, once you have the seared furnace, you can make grout more easily and without water, but for now you are limited to this.

To get unfired seared bricks is easy, however. You just stamp grout through a wooden brick form and you get it out. The wonders of technology!

There are many varieties of seeds in the world, even disregarding the pam's ones. The main ones to use early on are Actually Additions crops and Roots crops, as well as some vanilla ones.

Of note is that wildroot is gotten by either breaking tall grass or by cutting regular grass with your knife.
By burning an unfired seared brick in a fire to can make fired seared bricks! You can also throw in more than one at a time to make multiple.

betterquesting:10.name:8: Light The Fire Up In The Night
betterquesting:10.desc:8: Your first way of starting fire is with a match, fire is a very handy resource for cooking up objects and items, though it may be too fast and hot to make some items, like bricks. But the use of fire will definitely advance your civilization past the stone age.

Glass is a tricky material to get.

In order to make glass you have to burn glassy sand, which itself is a compound of glass dust and sand, with glass dust being a compound of sand dust and flint dust. While it's nothing expensive, it's quite a process.

For fluid collection, we'll need to start off with clay. It is a very primitive way of transporting fluids and breaks after placing down lava, but it will work for now. You get it by burning an unfired clay bucket into a fire for a few seconds. Don't worry, you won't loose the clay bucket.

Combining all of the materials at your disposal you should now be able to make a seared furnace. A proper improvement over firing or drying your items. Unfortunately, getting all the required ingredients wont be easy.

For the full multiblock you'll end up needing exactly 60 seared bricks, or just under a stack of bricks. All the seared bricks go into the components you see, 8 seared brick blocks arranged almost like a capped donut (a rough schematic is at the bottom of this text), a seared furnace controller, and a seared tank. You also need lava to power the furnace, and finding that could be an issue in and of itself. If you can't find lava for the life of you, you can use creosote oil just as well.

This quest also gives you a free lava florb, which basically acts as a throwable lava source. You can use this to power the furnace as well, but you're going to need a reliable source of lava at some point.

Minimum Furnace:

Top Layer

(air)       (air)        (air)
(air) (seared brick) (air)
(air)       (air)        (air)

Mid Layer

(seared brick) (seared brick) (seared brick)
(seared brick)        (air)       (seared brick)
(seared brick) (furnace cont.) (seared tank)

Bottom Layer

(air)       (air)        (air)
(air) (seared brick) (air)
(air)       (air)        (air)

Do you love charcoal? Of course you do! That's why you need to make yourself a coke oven. No seriously make it.

A coke oven provides two essential resources, charcoal and creosote (also coal coke, but you can choose whichever burnable product you want). Charcoal or Coal Coke acts as an effective fuel in boilers, while creosote is required for treated wood and also can be used in later boilers and as a fuel. In total this takes 120 coke clay.

Despite the JEI information saying otherwise, you don't need a coke oven hatch for it to work, which is why it is not required for this quest.
The Coke Oven Hatch acts as an output for the coke oven. If you place a tank behind it, the oven automatically outputes creosote into it. How awesome!
If you play on a new update of this pack, chances are that the questbook has changed. Completing this quest will reload the questbook, meaning you get all the new quests!

This pack has a fully customized ore generation and world generation system. This means that there is a lot of things you're going to need to know.

Firstly, caves do not generate. Ravines and other underground structures do generate, but there are no caves in this world. There are also no non-Gregtech ores, and all of those ores generate in large veins underground. These veins are massive and filled with tons of ores depending on the type of vein. Vein information can be found in JEI. (Note that the stone of each ore is interchangeable, basalt cassiterite is the same as granite cassiterite) These large veins generate on a consistent map of veins.

To find any one of these veins you need to find your coordinate of the chunk you are in (That is, your placement on the minecraft chunk grid, found by opening the F3 menu and looking at the second set of numbers in the Chunk listing, which is two below your XYZ coordinates) and only focus on the first and last values, we do not care about the middle one. Then, if both of those values are some sort of multiple of 3 plus 1, there is an ore vein there. §cThis includes negative signs§f§c, for example a vein would not spawn at 21 -34, but would spawn at 21 -32§f

Additionally, the harvest levels of the minerals are customized. Which means you can't get some materials before getting a certain tier of pickaxe. This is used to limit progression, luckily all the mining heads needed will be listed off in the questbook, so it should be fine *probably*. The harvest level of a block indicates the first material a pickaxe head can be made out of that mines at that level.

With your flint pickaxe you can really only mine a few basic ores, copper being one of them. The main places you will find copper this early on is in Bornite and Tenorite veins. For the chalcopyrite vein you can mine both the copper and chacopyrite ore, while with the bornite vein you can only mine the Chalcolite and Copper ore. Regardless, get some copper

With your flint pickaxe you can really only mine a few basic ores, tin being one of them. The main places you will find tin this early on is in Cassiterite Sand and Magnetite veins. For the Cassiterite sand vein you can mine everything in it, while with the Magnetite vein you can only mine the tin ore. Of note, the cassiterite sand smelts into tin as well.

The tinker's smeltery is the way to get into further metallurgy. Most importantly it can blend together alloys, which is what is required in order to get iron. It can also smelt them out into certain casts.

This quest shows the resources for the smallest possible smeltery but you are most certainly going to want something a bit bigger. This is just the minimum amount of material required to progress.

You can find and mine coal veins now, and while the coal itself is already pretty nice to have, coal coke is a way cooler material that burns for twice as long! All you need to do is put it through a coke oven.

Bronze is an alloy of 3 copper and 1 tin. You cannot make a dust blend for this alloy, so you have to alloy those two together in the smeltery. This alloy will be the basis for all of your steam machines, and is how to get higher tier metals.

You do not have access to gold or aluminium, which means you do not have any form of reusable cast, unless you want to smelt up the ingot cast each time. For now, the only casts you can use are out of clay. In my unending generousity, I will gift you some blank casts for this quest.
Just your regular, everyday, bricks. Nothing odd here.

betterquesting:10.name:8: The Dawn Of The Steam Age
betterquesting:10.desc:8:
Steam power is the first form of machinery you can get, and now you can finally make it.

None of the materials are especially much to get, and can all be gotten fairly easily, this steam machine runs off of burnable fuels, like coal, to heat up water. You must have a constant supply of water otherwise it will blow up. No one wants an explosion, do we?

1:10.command:8:
#Script Comment
say @s Has entered the Steam Age!

betterquesting:10.desc:8: Brick blocks are a sturdy block perfect for defending your base against most mobs. It's also an essential item for steam machines, which is probably why you'd make them.

Bronze is a pretty good material, might be a good idea to mine with it.

Bronze tools are the final step towards getting iron, they can harvest many more resources and are much faster than your dinky flint tools. pretty fun, amirite?

There are many sources of iron in the world, the main two being brown limonite veins and magnetite veins. With your bronze pickaxe you can now mine out both of them. Thus, you can now get IROOOOOOOOOOOON

Creosote is a handy byproduct of putting things through a coke oven, it can be used as a fuel source and as a way to make torches. You can also use to to make treated wood. Get creosote.

You just need to put the creosote in the bucket, BetterQuesting is good like that. Clay or Iron will work.

Bronze is a durable enough material to make proper tools out of, these tools in this quest will be the main ones you'll be using a lot. You also might want to consider upgrading your hammer, the stone one is pretty bad.

Personal advice? I'd wait off till Iron to do this, casting out all the bronze is kind of boring, but you can do it right now.

Wood is a pretty flimsy resource, why don't we treat it?

Treated wood allows for easier crafting of wooden items, like crafting tables, and the crafting of completely new items, like chests. It's a pretty neat resource isn't it?

Despite what the recipe says, you can use clay buckets for this as well.

With all of your newfangled tools, chests are now a definite possibility to make. They're a bit expensive, but it will be so, so worth it.

This quest is a crafting task, which means you can't just pick up a chest you got previously.

Finite water got you down? Don't fret! Infinite Water is here to save you! The water tank from railcraft generates a very tiny amount of water per tick, but it'll probably be enough to sustain you, at least for now.

The Slimeball can be gotten through either Tinkers Construct Slime Islands or Rice Slimeballs.

Note, unlike the 1.7.10 version, the 1.12.2 tank does not have a GUI, but it does still output water (Not automatically into GT pipes, however). So while it does generate water you can't see it do it in action.
Some Materials can only be mined with iron mining level or higher, thus you'll need iron tools

Redstone is a very essential wiring component, it is conductive and highly tensile... I'm just kidding! but it is required for many components required for further machines.

Redstone ore takes iron tools to mine, which you then can break with a hammer in world to get crushed redstone ore, crush it further with a hammer in a crafting grid and you get impure redstone dust. You can then throw it into a cauldron in order to obtain the actual redstone dust.

I mean, can it really be considered ore washing?

The cauldron allows for different dusts to be washed through it, this is required to get redstone, since mining it just yields the ore rather than any dust.

The Pam's Well is an infinite source of water, well isn't that just perfect! Unfortunately, water cannot be pumped out of it, it must be manually extracted with buckets. While this may substitute you for a small while, it will not work in late steam or LV, however it's still good for any crafting recipes requiring water.

Also of note, only iron buckets can pull water out of these. They're finicky, I know.

Those fancy borders around the quests actually mean something! A quest with a more rounded border is optional, and is mostly a recommendation on what to do, a quest with a kind of royal border is required to progress. Some quests are REALLY recommended even though they aren't technically required, these will just have a crowned border

Rounded Border = Optional, but recommended
Crowned Border = Necessary / Really recommended

§mdid you get the pun for this quest its icon is royal jelly, hah get it

Some alloys are just too complicated to be made in a tinkers smeltery, those alloys are basically every single one. Thus, you need alloy smelters to do the job. The steam alloy smelter can do any ULV tier (8 EU/tick) recipe for the alloy smelter. (This is true of all steam machines) This can be used to make bronze more efficiently and without pouring it out, or to make different, more complex alloys.

Red Alloy is a versatile early game resource, it is an alloy of four redstone and one copper and is used in some very early electronics. This item is most important for pistons, which we will see very shortly.

Aside from the six you made in the last quest, you will also need wire cutters. These can be used to (who guessed) cut plates into wires. You'll end up using these a lot later, but for now you just kind of need them.

Coke Ovens are painfully slow, and while you could just make more of them that'll produce way more creosote than you can reasonably handle, maybe lets try another way?

Forestry Charcoal Pits allow for mass production of charcoal, by making wood piles and encasing them in a solid square and then surrounding that on all of its open sides by some sort of block, you can go and start mass producing charcoal!

For now you only have access to three types of encasing blocks, Bricks, Coke Oven Bricks, and Seared Bricks. Out of all of these the coke oven bricks produce the best result, being a 1 to 1 ratio. You can see the amount of charcoal you get in JEI (If you minus the amount by 9, that is). Later on you can make ash bricks, and if you're really dedicated you can make Loam or Blast Furnace Bricks. But these structures should supply you for now.

The byproduct produced by these is Forestry ash, which unfortunately cannot be changed, so all Forestry ash can be crafted into GT ash, which can be used in recipes.

Despite how amazing these may seem, they can't be automated, so if you're sticking with steam you'll have to retire these at some point.

§cIMPORTANT! This has been mentioned previously but the amount in JEI that you see is NOT the amount rewarded by each block, however it is if you minus 9 from it. These structures can be effectively any sized cube you want. THe quest ONLY asks you make a wood pile. It does not matter what you encase it in.

Pushing things has never been so exhilirating!

Pistons are required for every single steam machine beyond this, so you're going to have to get them at one point or another. They aren't terrible to craft, only really taking two iron screws and red alloy, but these are an essential first component.
The Steam Furnace is a tad more efficient than a regular furnace, not like you'd know what that is. Regardless it could be nice to have depending on how much you hate your Seared Furnace.
The Steam Compressor is a very handy item, for one it now allows you to make blocks of metals, and for another... Well we'll see what else it does soon. Regardless, make it. Now.

betterquesting:10.name:8: The "Please don't use this to double your iron" Machine
betterquesting:10.desc:8:
The Steam Macerator allows you to macerate things with steam, surprisingly. These range from ores to just general blocks, and it has more utility than the regular mortars! Unfortunately, this machine is slow. Very Slow. At least with ores you're probably fine macerating clay. Anyways, only use this for doubling ores when they are very valuable

Diamonds can be found in Graphite veins, which are very low down. If you haven't found them already.
For rubber, you're going to need to extract rubber pulp out of some sticky resin. We'll explain how to get sticky resin later, but you will need an extractor later

Do you have armor? Would you like to keep that armor? Well good news for you you can now make an anvil! Since the casting basin has been disabled, your only choice to make iron blocks is through a compressor, and you'll need a few of those to make an anvil. It's expensive but oh so worth it.

The Steam Forge Hammer is an amazing item, it allows you to turn 3 ingots into 2 plates, how amazing! It may not seem like a significant change, but it starts to add up over time. It's very much recommended you make this machine, especially when doing piping.

The steam mixer can be used to mix things. You can use it this early on to make things like dough more efficiently so if you're a big foodie, it's recommended to make this. It's also required for making concrete later on.

Maybe GT Small Steam Coal Boilers dont suit your fancy? Maybe not even all the other boilers can satisfy your need for steam. We're gonna have to go bigger

The Railcraft Boilers act very similar to GT Boilers, they both take time and heat to prduce steam, however, Railcraft boilers only output steam when over 50% of their internal buffer is full, meaning they won't instantly heat up and produce steam, and also they require some form of pressure tank above. Without any steel you can only make the Solid Fueled Boiler and the Low Pressure tank. You can make these bigger, however this quest shows the minimum possible for a railcraft boiler.

The boilers will form a multiblock and output from the tank on top. Water must be imported on the boiler section.

Yep, that'll do.

In order to progress further in machinery you'll need the Engineer's Workbench for many recipes. Not just mechanical components but also your first circuits and other features. Also make an engineer's hammer, if you haven't already.

You're also going to need blueprints in order to do any crafting in a workbench, right now you really only have to care about the crafting components blueprint, since none of the others are necessary currently. This is why the quest only cares that you get the crafting components blueprint.

Calling them circuits is a bit misleading

Your first "circuits" you can obtain will be Vacuum Tubes, these are used for both ULV machines and also your first LV circuits, we'll talk about both of those later, right now you're gonna need them, and plan on making a lot of them. Make sure you start stocking up on all of your ores, and maybe think about getting that Steam Macerator if you haven't already.

betterquesting:10.name:8: High Pressure Tank and Liquid Boiler
betterquesting:10.desc:8:
You want to improve your railcraft steam? Of course you do! Making a High Pressure Tank will allow for more steam to be produced, while the liquid fueled boiler allows for liquids, like creosote, to be used in the process of making steam. Both of these components take steel and either of them can be used to complete the quest.

Now let's get even more steam!

Wrought Iron is a more durable version of Iron that can be used for tools, and is required for high pressure steam machines and steel (More on both of those later). However, making Wrought Iron isn't as simple as just smelting iron, oh no. In order to make wrought iron you need to put iron (And some sort of fuel) through a bloomery, which will be your first multiblock.

The Bloomery is a multiblock designed solely for making wrought iron. It will take a lot of iron and bricks, but the materials in general aren't to hard to obtain. However, there is one slight difference. Each recipe takes two inputs and makes two outputs, however your currently available buses (ULV) only have 1 input slot and 1 output slot. This means you need 2 ULV input and output buses in order to actually have the multiblock work.

Other than that it's pretty simple, and you can see a preview of the multiblock in JEI. Note that you can rotate the multiblock vertically by hold shift while dragging your mouse. Other than that it's fairly self explanatory, now get that iron!
Calcite is a material found in lazurite veins sporadically, and can only be mined with Wrought Iron level pickaxes or above. Can be used to make concrete.
Some ores can only be mined with pickaxes wrought iron level or above, so you're going to have to upgrade your pick once again.
Gypsum is a material that found in Basaltic Mineral Sand veins sporadically, it is used to make Firebricks. It can only be mined with a Wrought Iron Mining Level or above.

Liquid Concrete is a mix of Calcite dust, stone dust, sand dust, clay dust, and water. While it can't be used to make concrete at a 4 to 1 ratio, it's still able to be made, it is also used for firebricks. 

Of note is that it doesn't produce a full bucket amount of concrete, however you can just bucket it up with a wooden tank which you can get after a macerator, this will allow for far less hassle when transferring liquids between inventorys.

Alternatively: What's Baking Good.... yeah ive got nothing

You've been pretty sufficiently fed up to this point probably, Getting food from each and every quest and the likes, well in the future do not expect to be getting hamburgers for making a new tool, you're going to have to feed yourself at some point, you know. That's why you need to start baking.

The Baking Oven from GregTech Food Option is a very early game multiblock that can do a number of operations normal furnaces can't, like baking bread or bacon or a multitude of other food items, this is your first proper way of making food, enjoy.

The multiblock uses mainly adobe brick blocks, adobe brick being able to be made in a multitude of different ways. This quest shows the way to make it using the most expensive recipe, just sand, gravel, and clay. If you want to you could use wheat in some fashion but you're alone on those calculations then

If you want to store steam to get a backlog you're gonna need something better than some flimsy tanks and drums, you'll be needing something way better than that. There are currently two options for getting massive storage of liquids, those being the Railcraft Iron Tank and the Tinkers Tank. They both can assuredly store your steam or creosote supplies, it's purely a matter of preference. The Tinker's Tank takes much less materials (mostly just a lot of seared bricks), but the Iron Tank stores 4x as much liquid per square block compared to the Tinkers Tank. 

Additionally, the Iron Tank can auto-output to GT pipes with a valve placed on the bottom middle, which the Tinkers Tank can't do, thus, if you are using the Tinker's Tank, you can't use GT pipes and must use Fluiducts or Mekanism Pipes. The Iron Tank needs the gauges to be in the center front two blocks, while everything else is iron tank walls and valves, the valves being the input and output for the liquid.

The Tinker Tank needs to have liquids inputted through the drains and the tank controller in the bottom-front center. Besides that it's basically still just a square. You dont need seared glass to complete the multiblock but it's cheap and looks nice so why not? The center for both of these tanks are hollow except for the top and bottom. Reminder that this tank can't be outputted from automatically with GT pipes (it can be inputted into, however).

The quest allows for either of these tanks to be built to complete it. The Iron Tank must at minimum be built as a 3x3x4 (Length x Width x Height) structure, while the Tinkers Tank can be at minimum a 3x3x3. This quest also shows the requirements for two tanks both of the size 3x3x4.
Can only be made by putting Wrought Iron in a Primitive Blast Furnace.

Steel is the next biggest advancement you'll be coming up on.

Steel needs to be made in the Primitive Blast Furnace, and is used for... everything? You need a lot of steel going onwards. Unfortunately, the PBF needs a lot of materials to make, and will be a major investment. But, this quest will show you what you need.

There's not many important things to note about the crafting process, you macerate, you compress, you smelt. The firebricks are fairly simple. The only really complicated thing may be the concrete, since the mixer recipe doesn't come out in whole-number amounts. This quest shows the §cMINIMUM §famount of calcite, and stone, and such needed. Make sure to complete one step and then move on to the next, since otherwise betterquesting gets messed up and will not count it.

The PBF is a 3x3x4 multiblock, that has an empty column in the middle except for the bottom block, this means that the top center block is exposed to air, or just in general isn't a firebrick. The PBF item goes into the front-middle of the second layer. If you get confused just check the item description in JEI.

High Pressure steam machines run much faster than the default steam machines, so if you don't want to rush into LV, you should make these. Regardless this quest only asks for the casing and hull for the machines, there are no individual quests for the high pressure steam machines. Anything taking these machines is just run off from this quest

Advanced Alloy is a compressed version of a possible blend of many different plates. Though the easiest to do right now would be with tin, iron, and bronze. It's a component for advanced glass and some higher tier machines.

The most powerful oven since 1982

The steam oven is a large multiblock that smelts 8 items at a time at the cost of (who'd guess it) steam. The oven is a structure with a 3x3 base, a 3x3 middle with a hollow center, and a 3x1 set of casings at the top. If you need any help building it look at the structure preview in JEI.

For both steam multiblocks you need steam buses and a steam hatch. The steam buses are fairly simple, while the steam hatch just takes some bronze and a tank. This quest shows all the materials you need for it. Of note is that the steam hatch must go on the bottom layer and the steam buses must go in the middle layer.

With this you are now a proper smelter!

Maybe your Iron Tank still isn't sufficing you, maybe you need something even bigger, maybe you need the power of steel.

A Steel tank holds twice the storage of an iron tank and eight times the storage of a tinker tank of equal size, If your tinker tank isn't suiting you this certaintly will.

Same rules apply to this tank, outputs from the bottom, inputs from any of the side, basically built in the same way as an iron tank, but steel. A lot of steel. Might need some more blast furnaces for that.
Some ores take steel mining level, also steel is awesome. make a steel pickaxe head.

With your newfound steel pickaxe, you can now start getting obsidian. Obsidian is a strong material, and good for building your bases with, but because of how long it takes to mine, you might want to think about using materials that just take a bit of obsidian rather than obsidian itself. Even then there's still something you want to make taking obsidian... Nonetheless, get that rock!

Matches are a bit outdated, why not use flint and steel!

Because you now have steel, flint and steel is a very good investment. It's more permanent than both matches and match boxes, so if you burn a lot or want to hurt smokey the bears feelings by burning down multiple forests, it's a great choice!

Let's go to hell!

The nether is a dangerous place, with fire and lava and very deadly enemies everywhere, you want to be careful there. But it is your first way of getting gold and sulfur so it is necessary to go there to progress. Make sure to bring plenty of food and armor with you, it's gonna be dangerous

Electric Motors are a powerful tool to have, and will allow you to make your first ULV machines, the ULV Electric Motors, like your Vacuum Tubes, must be made in a engineers worktable. If you haven't already, make a Forge Hammer, it makes the wires way less horrible to make.

Let's get some electricity up in this bi-atch!

No LV Machines are currently accesable, so we're gonna have to use the only tier of machine available to us, ULV. We'll cover electricty more in depth later, but for right now you have to know some very basic things, 1. Don't overpower your machines (Basically stick with ULV wires, preferably red alloy since it's lossless) and 2. Dont overpower your cables (Good luck getting battery storage). Nonetheless, let's get a steam turbine!

The main materials for ULV machines are red alloy and tin alloy, So make sure you have plenty of copper, redstone, iron, and tin in supply. 

For a Primitive Steam Turbine you need 2 tin alloy rotors, 1 ULV circuits (so Vacuum Tubes) 2 ULV Motors, 2 Medium Wood pipes, a ULV Machine hull, and a red alloy cable. The previous two quests showed you how to make ULV motors and Vacuum tubes, and you already made red alloy cable and ULV machine hulls for your Bloomery, all that's left is the tin alloy rotors, each of them takes 4 curved plates so if you haven't already MAKE A FORGE HAMMER. It is the cheapest way to make plates until LV, so you're going to want it. The ring and screw are nothing special, so it shouldn't be an issue

With all those ingredients together you can now make the truly powerful and incredible Primitive Steam Turbine, POWAH!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Wrought Iron can heat up pretty well, but you want to know what's better? Steel. Make a steel heater, you need them for Steam Multiblocks

If you want to go getting the max output possible now, you could use your regular macerator for all your ores, but that's slow and just a really dumb idea. You want to go with a steam grinder.

The steam grinder takes mostly the same components as the steam oven, so if you havent already you should check that quest, the only real difference is the diamond grinding head, which shouldn't be an issue. The multiblock can run 8 items at once but that take 1.5x the base duration of that one item, so it becomes more effective the more items you put into it. The structure is built as a hollow 3x3x3 structure, with any of the bronze metal casings being able to be replaced with the buses or hatch. 

This still wont allow you to double gem-like ores. Like Diamond or Coal. But it'll allow you to get more product out of iron, copper, cassiterite, and other important ores.

Molds are pretty handy! They allow for making things like rods and gears for cheaper! At least, later they will. Right now you only have an alloy smelter so you can only use alloy smelter molds, later if you get an Extruder you can use extruder molds to a much greater effect. Either way, gather all of these molds since they are incredibly nice and cut down a lot on resource cost and will help keep your tools alive.

Plate Mold: Used to GT Glass Panes
Ingot Mold: Makes bricks and coke bricks cheaper
Ball Mold: Used for Glass Tubes
Gear Mold: Cost of gears cut down
Small Gear Mold: Cost of small gears cut down

The ULV Polarizer is one of the four ULV machines you can make, it's use is pretty much limited to making the magnetic steel required for LV motors. This machine doesn't take any ULV components whatsoever, so it is incredibly cheap, so why wait to make it.

A ULV component

Is not an actual piston

A ULV Component

Does not actually transfer stacks

In order to make LV circuits, and thus get into LV, you need to use an Assembler to make primitive processors, without access to an LV assembler, that leaves only one option, the ULV Assembling Machine.

This is a very expensive machine, requiring a total of eight motors in all just to build, however not only is it required to make LV circuits, it can also do things like make furnaces and bookshelves way cheaper and also allows you to build better tanks (More on that later). So it's a worthwhile investment.

Any ULV Machine can only do recipes that take 8 EU per tick (EU/t) max, alternatively JEI shows the tier an assembler needs to be at to make a recipe.

A ULV Component

Does not pump fluids

A ULV Component, the most expensive one.

Does not actually work as a cover.

I promise this is the last one of those with a bad name

Rustic Alchemy takes some plants, some of them you can't find just yet but others are found dotted throughout the overworld, the ones shown here are the only ones you can use in basic alchemy. So go grab some plants and probably subsequently plant them

If a brewing stand isn't available, try the next best thing!

Rustic Alchemy allows you to brew elixirs, with the current supplies and tier of alchemy you have you can really only make three of them, a healing potion, a regeneration potion, and a swiftness potion. The only odd ingredient that isn't obvious is honeycombs, which come from Rustic Bees and Rustic Bees alone in a Rustic Apiary.

Brew yourself some elixirs to help get you out of a bad situation, knowing this pack you'll need it at some point.

Roots is a mod about using nature's aura in order to become more powerful, There are two forms of magic in Roots, that being rituals and spells. We'll be focusing on spells for now since that's the most important thing to us

In order to cast spells you need a type of spell dust, a staff, and an imbuer. First, place down the imbuer and then put the spell you want to infuse your staff with into the imbuer, and then place the wand there too. After a short amount of time your staff should be successfully imbued with the respective spell!

You can add up to five spells to a single staff, and can switch between them by shift-right clocking. However using each spell takes a certain amount of components (Seen in the tooltip of the spell dust itself), it can either take these components from your inventory or take them from a component pouch, which stores much more of them, it can hold six stacks of components to be used currently, and it also stores twelve stacks of items, it's like a mini-backpack! (The rightmost inventory is for components, the left one is for general storage).

Most spells don't consume a whole number amount of resources, so for most of these early spells you wont have to worry too much about running out, even then most of the components are renewable and growable. The only exception now is Terra Moss, because you'd have to find either vines or mossy cobblestone, which are both not extremely common. I recommend trying to find a tall forestry tree, since those usually have veins, or look for a biome like a Jungle or Lush Swamp.

That about covers everything with spells! This quest solely asks for the Imbuer and Staff, nothing else. We can talk about specific spells later.

The first roots crop you're going to want to make is the Cloud Berry, this is, importantly, used to make the Fey Crafter, and is thus a pretty key item for Fey Crafting. It must be made in a Pyre using Wool, Cloudsbluff (Another Rustic Plant in the Overworld), Biomes O' Plenty Berries, Terra Moss, and a Speed Elixir. Most of those materials you have probably just stumbled across on your escapades, so it is not terribly difficult.

Later you can grow these crops but that is LV which is not where you are right now.

One of the most important mechanisms in Roots is the Fey Crafter, which allows you to craft items using the power of Feys, that's probably the lore behing it.

There are three parts to Fey Crafting, the Crafter itself, the Grove Stone, and the spell "Grove Supplication", imbued onto a staff. The Fey Crafter is what will be used for actual crafting operations, while the Grove Stone is able to make those crafters usable in a radius around it when given the Grove Supplication spell. Basically, you craft with the Fey Crafter which needs a powered Grove Stone in order for it to work.

After imbuing your staff with the Grove Supplication Spell, you can then use it near a grove stone in order to allow it to do Fey Crafting rituals, putting your ingredients on the pedestal and then wacking it with a knife will get you the item you are trying to make!

This quest asks for both the Grove Stone, the Fey Crafter, and the Supplication Spell Dust. The only things that are worth to note about these recipes are the greatwood leaves, menril logs, and silverwood saplings used in the Fey Crafter, these Trees naturally generate in the world fairly uncommonly, but it shouldn't be too impossible with some exploring.

Now you can get to Fey Crafting!

GregTech's Rubber Trees do not naturally generate in the world, rather you're going to have to make your first Rubber Trees using Roots. It takes two slimeballs of some type, a greatwood sapling, terra spores, and Wildroot, none of which should be hard to get.

§cThis is the only way of making raw resin, there is no other way to do it. (Working on removing the other recipes)

Rubber is a very flexible and versatile material, it's used to coat wires, to make soft mallets, and is required for quite a lot of machines and components coming forth. Rubber can be made later in a chemical reactor, but for right now it needs to be made in an alloy smelter

To make a rubber bar you need four raw resin pulp and two sulfur dust. Raw resin pulp is gotten from extracting raw resin, which is gotten from GT rubber trees, and sulfur dust, which is gotten (unsurprisingly) from sulfur

All FE (That is to say all RF, or MJ or whatever traditional power sources are) generators have been removed §c(still being worked on), §fwhich means that you can only use GT generators to make power, to power your FE machines, you'll have to turn that GT power into FE power, which means you need a GTEU Energy Converter going from GTEU to FE.

There are 4 GTEU to FE energy converters that can be made, a 1x, a 4x, a 8x, and a 16x. However these machines dont care about Amperage, so all that it changes is how much FE is pumped out, for the first ULV one its 32 FE/tick for the 16x ULV one its 512 FE/tick.

It should be noted that GTEU and FE do not have a 1 to 1 conversion ratio, it is 4 to 1, meaning for each single unit of GTEU that's used you get 4 units of FE. The input of GTEU into the device comes from any normal side while the side with the red dot is where FE is outputted from.

This quest asks for the 1x one, since it's the cheapest to make and also probably the only one you'll need to make. You also do not need batteries for these to run, but they will hold less internal energy

Immersive Engineering is the first FE-based mod you have access to, and it's wires are also the first FE transfer wires you have access to, right now its LV wires and relays are more than good enough, so let's make that

For a brief overview of how IE wires work, Connectors are placed on objects to output or input FE, and can only hold one connection, while Relays are able to hold more than one connection but cannot input or output FE into a machine

Maybe you don't want to make a new iron tank or tinkers tank every time you get a new liquid to mess with, once you start working with chemicals you'll understand why. Maybe you need semi-permanent fairly extensive single block storage, maybe Industrial Tanks are what you're looking for.

Industrial Tanks function as lighter versions of quantum tanks, only holding a few dozen buckets instead of a few thousand. The first one you can craft is a Primitive Industrial Tank, which stores 32 buckets.

In order to make tin wires for LV you're going to need a way to wrap them, the only way to do it this early is with an immersive engineering bottler.

The bottling machine is a multiblock from immersive engineering, however how to build it will not be described here, check the Immersive Engineering manual instead for how to build this machine. The requirements for it are three conveyer belts, three steel scaffolding, two iron sheetmetal, two light engineering blocks, one redstone engineering block, one fluid pump, and one block of glass, as well as probably a hopper to do slight automation with it.

Most of the crafting for this components is self explanatory, when you construct it you must hit the center conveyer belt with an immersive hammer for the structure to form, if it doesnt form check the manual again and also make sure the conveyers are pointing in the same direction. Which is to say they go forward from the iron sheetmetal to the light engineering blocks. power must go into the orange plug on the top of where the light engineering blocks were put, attaching a LV connector there and wiring it up will work. A hopper can be placed next to the conveyers in the direction they're traveling in order to do semi-automation with it, if a hopper isnt used the item wanting to be bottled can just be thrown on the conveyer belt.

Liquids are pumped into the blue input plug on the back of where the iron sheetmetal was, fluiducts/mek pipes will work for this. Other than that, that's pretty much all there is to know, have fun bottling!

An essential LV crafting component, for now must be made in the bottler.

In order to get molten rubber to coat the wires you have to melt rubber ingots in a smeltery and then output it to the bottler using a smeltery drain connected to some sort of fluid pipe. It takes two ingots to make one cable.

Another step towards LV! LV Machine Hulls are required for each LV machine, much like the previous ULV hulls, so you're going to need a lot of these, it just takes steel, wrought iron, and some tin cables, so they aren't terribly difficult.

ULV motors are a tad old, let's make ULV motors!

They can only be made with magnetic steel rods, magnetic iron is not gonna cut it. They also take four copper wires and two tin cable

Note: Magnetic Steel can be made in a ULV polarizer, it only takes 8 EU/t now.

Resistors are an integral part of LV circuits, let's get some Resistors.

The only really strange component is the fine copper wire, taking copper foil which needs copper plates, but other than that you should've already seen the materials.

I can see the horizon, you are almost free of Steam and ULV!!

LV Circuits are an integral part of every LV machine bar a few exceptions, so be expecting to make a lot of these. The circuits can only be made in an assembling machine, and they take two vacuum tubes, two resistors, three red alloy cable, a circuit board, and a steel plate. Other than the circuit board you have made all of them previously, and the Circuit board itself is also fairly simple. Without access to a Centrifuge you only have access to the recipe using Copper Wire, which is more costly, unfortunately.

Putting all of those components into your ULV Assembling machine will get you the amazing Primitive Processor!! Your first LV Circuit, congrats!!

betterquesting:10.name:8: The Future Is Now, Old Man
betterquesting:10.desc:8:
Your first form of LV power generation, and your gateway to every other LV machine.

Most of the materials for a turbine have been gotten already, all that it really takes now are the two tin rotors, but you already made tin alloy rotors, so I don't feel the need to explain it again, just the same as previously but with tin.

Congrats on unlocking LV!

§cAlso you cant use a transformer to get LV power, that's been disabled.

2:10.command:8:
#Script Comment
say @p has completed "Age 0 - The Steam Age"!

betterquesting:10.name:8: You Didn't Think It Would Be That Simple Did You?
betterquesting:10.desc:8: After you've been mining gravel for a bit you may say "Hey! This gravel isn't dropping any flint!", keen eye esteemed player, gravel no longer drops flint in this pack! Instead the first way to get flint is to sift through gravel by shift-right clocking it. That will get you flint shards which you can turn into flint,

BQ not only allows for quests it also allows for questlines, the questlines in this pack are sorted top down and the general pattern for them goes as follows

1st Tier: Overall Progression, Main Voltage Tiers of GT
2nd Tier: Non-GT Tech Mods (Mekanism, AE2)
3rd Tier: Magic Mods (Roots, Thaumcraft)
4th Tier: Quality of Life Tools (Armor, Weapons)
5th Tier: Additional Information

It's fairly easy to tell when the tiers switch, as well.

betterquesting:10.name:8: "Hey You Should Really Read The Questbook"
betterquesting:10.desc:8: This is just a reminder that you 100% definitely and are incredibly recommended to read the questbook, You should also try to make your own things but most of the time everything gets explained in the Questbook.

Leather armor is a good armor for the early game. In a stage where iron is hard to come by, leather makes for a good substitute if you get yourself into some trouble. You can also make it out of woven cotten, which may be cheaper depending on what you've been growing.

Or Woman, if you prefer

Iron armors' recipes has been changed, now taking iron plates and bended iron plates, which is kind of expensive, either way you should craft yourself some iron armor, more durable and strong than leather so even better for running away.

Wires are really REALLY annoying to craft, right now we turn 1.5 ingots optimally into only 1 wire! lets turn 1 ingot into 2 wires now, shall we?

The Wiremill is going to definitely be your first machine, unless you really want to make plates more efficiently, but you probably want to make wires more efficiently instead, anyways, the Wiremill gets you a lot of wires very fast, very handy. Only just takes a lot of motors really (but after this you'll never worry about motors again).

Hey remember that Primitive Blast Furnace you made? You should make 3 more of those

Machines can share walls, building these all in a square sort of formation is the cheapest way to make 4 PBFs run

betterquesting:10.name:8: Wait. What Machines Should I Make????
betterquesting:10.desc:8:
If you're new to Gregtech you may be intimidated by the large amount of machines you can make, don't be!
LV opens up a lot of new machines, unlike ULV, LV has a bunch of machines available to you right out of the gate, some more useful than others. Your main priority starting out will be to get more efficient materials, that is wires, plates, and rods. For those you'll want a wiremill, bending machine, and lathe respectively. Early on you should also make machines to deprecate your old singleblock steam machines, as they are far less efficient than using LV. It's also recommended to soon make machines for much cheaper rubber.
After that it's mostly making machines like assemblers and chemical baths, machines that reduce the amount of resources you'll be using. Once you start making assemblers and other doo-dads you're pretty much free to do whatever you want

There is no goal for this quest, just letting you know kind of what to expect!

You know what? Pistons are good, let's make them better

LV Electric Pistons are a very important component for a lot of machines, and can even be used to make pistons very efficiently. Not much else to say here, they're a useful component.

With your newfound steel production you can now make a tool forge! It takes a lot of steel though, but it is so worth it to get those better tools.

§cNote: Only one of the tool forges shown in JEI are able to be crafted, the rest aren't. We don't know why JEI doesn't remove them.§c

The forge hammer is pretty good, turning three ingots into two plates and all that. But what if we could do better?

The Basic Bending Machine is a machine that allows for you to turn one plate into one ingot, which will make pretty much every single thing cheaper, after the wiremill this is the second machine you are going to want to make. 

The only odd part about the bending machine is what it needs to make plates (and other bendable materials, I suppose), and that's the integrated circuit. To get it you just put an LV circuit in a crafting grid, and to configure it you right click it in-world. Every plate takes configuration 1.

Enjoy your new plate maker!

Or as Avi calls it "Quite possibly the worst machine"

The Lathe is able to make rods, however unlike the extruder, which will end up being able to double rod output, the Lathe only does 1.5x output§c*§f It's not a drastic improvement and is exceedingly slow, but it's the best you got in LV since the only way to double rods takes an extruder which you can only get in MV.

Nonetheless, moving away from the file is a fairly good idea.

§c*If you're a literal min-maxing god for all technical purposes the output of rods from a lathe ends up asympoting to 2x output. nerd.

You have been mocked relentlessly by this cruel, cruel world. It is time to strike back at it and overrule it. You hear legends of a powerful tool, an item that can be used to level deserts and bring Gaia to her knees, although the price is hefty it may be the only thing you can do to prevent becoming victim to the world at large. For when the earth spirits laugh at you for so long it is only a matter of time until you are at their throats.
Able to store more foods than a flimsy lunch bag, get a lunch box!

The mob spawning in GTOW is different than how it is in the vanilla game, Therefore you're going to want to know the intricacies of the mobs and what the expect during the night time

What you should know now is that in this stage you will only encounter zombies, skeletons, and spiders. No creepers, enderman, nothing like that, just those three hostile mobs. However the further you get in the game the harder they become and the more that can spawn.

Luckily the Quest Book has a set of quests in "Survive the Night" that documents all of the important progression points for each stage. This quest is telling you about those quests.

Incidentally, you should consider hiding in the ground because by the time you're reading this it's probably close to nighttime.

There are only three hostile mobs that spawn in the beginning

Zombies, Skeletons, and Spiders
These spawn normally with no changes to them. Passive mobs also obviously spawn

Once you complete the quest for the Small Steam Coal Boiler the Steam Age unlocks

This makes creepers, witches, zombie villagers, and cave spiders spawn.
This also makes zombies and skeletons have a chance to spawn with either a stone sword or a wooden axe

Your tools are good but are not up to mark. They may be great at digging out ores but making larger areas takes far more effort. There are many remedys to this, but you hear of one Snake Oil Salesman who has a tool which can fill your wildest satisfactions. A tool that is unbreakable, and mines in a 3x3 shape, my how magnificent! The cost is steep but the reward will be magnificent, what could be the downside?
Welcome to GTOW! This chapter will hopefully get you through the basics of the starting points to the pack
Nikola Tesla got NOTHING on these bad bois

Only a fool would build such powerful machines, or would they?

This is your multiblock questline. Filled with the biggest and most powerful machines you can ever make. Most quests here will be in the main line, however.
The beginning of magic! Wholely import to any master of the elements.

We gotta rock down to- Electric Avenue

Machines in this tier use 32 EU/t
This pack has a completely customized system for spawning mobs that causes them to become incredibly difficult in the late game. In this line we learn how to survive the night.

We cannot just survive everything thrown our way. We must thrive. We must win.

This is a special chapter dedicated for "grind" quests, quests that take an innumerable amount of resources to finish. These quests often have epic rewards but a hefty price. These are nonessential to completing the pack.
